Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Terahertz Measurement Systems based on Heterogeneously Integrated Sensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The terahertz (or submillimeter-wave) region of the electromagnetic spectrum has long been understood as crucial to fundamental scientific inquiry and progress in fields such as radio astronomy, atmospheric physics, and remote sensing. Moreover, new and emerging device concepts promise to open this largely-inaccessible spectrum to further scientific study as well as important applications in imaging, non-destructive test and evaluation, and high-bandwidth communications. Unfortunately, the infrastructure and measurement tools needed to develop these new technologies remain severely limited. Current approaches to realizing measurement instrumentation at submillimeter wavelengths are based largely on a modular approach using waveguide interfaces. This results in fully-assembled measurement apparatus with considerable geometric footprint that can prove unwieldy or unsuitable for many important scenarios, for example in situations when the device or system to test must be maintained within a shielded enclosure such as a vacuum chamber or cryostat. This project is focused on addressing this critical issue through the development of compact and low-profile measurement instruments that are based on high-performance terahertz sensors heterogeneously integrated with micromachined support membranes that allow direct-contact in situ characterization of planar devices and systems at terahertz frequencies. As a consequence, this work will have broad impact on the growing terahertz research community through the availability of new and advanced metrological instrumentation that permit measurements that presently are not possible or feasible. The creation of new measurement techniques and capabilities is fundamental to the advancement of science; scientific discovery and progress in engineering are predicated on the creation of instruments that open new physical domains for experimentation and inquiry. This work represents an initial, critical, and necessary step towards developing instruments that overcome the inherent drawbacks limiting current approaches to terahertz metrology.

The goal and scope of this project is to advance the infrastructure for measurement and characterization of terahertz devices, components, and systems through the development of instrumentation technologies that are based on heterogeneous integration. The research pursued focuses on heterogeneous integration across materials systems (e.g., III-V semiconductors and silicon) and across physical domains (e.g., electronics and mechanics). Towards this end, the specific approach to be undertaken includes three primary thrusts: (1) development of processing technologies for low-parasitic terahertz Schottky diode sensors heterogeneously integrated onto thin silicon membranes, (2) investigation and implementation of silicon membrane-based micromachined on-wafer probes incorporating integrated Schottky sensors, and (3) research and prototyping of compact, high-order terahertz frequency multiplier sources for integration with test and measurement instrumentation based on heterogeneous integration. There is inherent intellectual merit in researching processes that enable such integration and a significant effort of this proposal is dedicated to investigating methods that permit fabrication of high-performance terahertz electronic sensors with mechanically-robust host substrates amenable to direct, physical contact interfaces without need for fixturing. Fundamental issues of terahertz device design, fabrication technology, and metrology will be addressed during this work with the aim of realizing new and advanced instrumentation that permit measurements that presently are not possible or feasible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key outcomes of this project are (1) a new epitaxy transfer and heterogeneous integration process for implementing GaAs Schottky diodes on micromachined silicon substrates that provide superior robustness compared to previous fabrication methods, (2) demonstration and characterization of the thermal performance of the quasi-vertical diodes, showing their superior cooling characteristics compared to flip-chip mounted diodes in addition to robustness with regard to temperature cycling between room temperature and cryogenic (4 K) operation, (3) demonstration of an electronic calibration method that permits diodes to be used as impedance standards for submillimeter-wave on-wafer measurements, and (4) designs and initial fabrication steps for micromachined wafer probes with integrate diode-based sensors.

 

Diode Process Development:

A major result of this work was the development of a robust epitaxy transfer and heterogeneous integration process for fabricating submillimeter-wave GaAs Schottky diodes on high-resistivity silicon. The ability to micromachined the silicon substrate through post backside processing permits a fully-integrated diode-based platform that incorporates beamlead contacts, an integrated interposer, or RF circuitry on a full micromachined probe. The process developed and refined  through this program sought to address several deficiencies that limited the yield of heterogeneously-integrated diodes based on the original  approach that included annealed ohmic contacts and high-temperature wafer bonding. To obtain a smooth ohmic contact surface for the wafer bonding of GaAs onto 

silicon and also low ohmic contact resistance for low seriesresistance for the Schottky diodes with a repeatable process with high yield, a non-alloyed ohmic contact on GaAs epitaxy structure with graded InxGa1-xAs cap layers was incorporated. The non-alloyed formation of the ohmic contact eliminates the surface roughness resulting in thermally-annealed contacts andeliminated wafer fracture issues observed in the previous process. These contacts were found to yield low specific contact resistance measurements (8e-7Ohm cm-2), nearly the same as that obtained with annealed contacts.

Diode RF and Thermal Characterization:

A significant effort of this work was on fully characterizing the  parasitic environment of the quasi-vertical diode as well as its thermal performance. Diodes processed using the refined fabrication method were characterized at RF frequencies (up to 500 GHz, on wafer) and exhibited excellent performance comparable to other submillimeter-wave diodes designed for submillimeter-operation. This effort included fabrication of diode structures that permitted the parasitic elements associated with the diode geometry to be measured directly. 

Electronic Calibration 

Calibration and error correction are critical aspects of characterizing submillimeter-wave devices and errors associated with connectivity and repeatability limit precision. Consequently, one thrust of this effort was focused on developing electronic calibration approaches for on-wafer measurements at submillimeter-wave frequencies. In this research effort a proof-of-concept demonstration of on-wafer electronic calibration in the submillimeter-wave band (325—500 GHz) was developed. A GaAs Schottky diode shunting a coplanar transmission line was employed as an electronic standard that is tuned by bias applied through wafer probes. Error-corrected scattering parameter measurements, based on a Thru-Reflect- Line (TRL) calibration were used to characterize the on-wafer diode and establish it as a standard for electronic calibration. Subsequently, ensembles of measurements from a multiline TRL calibration and the diode calibration standard were performed and compared to assess the uncertainty associated with the two approaches. It was found that the error coefficients estimated using the electronic standard were in good agreement with those found from the multiline TRL calibration. Moreover, the electronic standard exhibited a significant improvement in precision compared with the TRL standards, consistent with previous work showing that error in probe placement between measurements was a principle source of uncertainty for TRL-based calibration.

Sensors on Probe Development

The final area of progress over the this program has been on the development and fabrication of micromachined wafer probes with integrated diode sensors. Three integrated probes are currently under development: a GaAs diode temperature sensor probe that utilizes the temperature-dependent IV characteristics of the diode as a thermometer, a prove with integrated diode power detector, and a six-port reflectometer-based probe for the WR-1.5 (500—750 GHz) band that incorporates an ensemble of diode power sensors to allow on-wafer s-parameter measurements without a backend network analyzer. Designs of the prototype probes with integrated sensor were completed, simulated, and mask designs/fabrication process for the devices finalized. Processing of the probes commenced in the fall of 2019 and currently the set of integratd probes are three-quarters of the way through fabrication. Completion of the integrated probes has been delayed due to the renovation of the University of Virginia Microfabrication Laboratory in addition to the state-wide shut down in March 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Once the cleanroom is opened, these probes will completed and tested.
